Award.AwardTitle: Computation of the Semiclassical Limit of Schroedinger's Equation, Anisotropic Grain Growth, and Epitaxial Growth Using Kinetic Monte Carlo
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal involves three projects where each one builds from prior NSF support. This first project involves the simulation of grain boundary motion in two and three dimensions using our recently developed multiphase variational level set framework. It is planned to extend this formulation to allow for the possibility of arbitrary surface tension between grains. This will be accomplished by combining this formulation with minimizing movements. The second project concerns the efficient computation the semi-classical limit of the Schroedinger equation. The proposed algorithm is based on the observation that if one transforms the Schroedinger equation using a transformation inspired by Gaussian wave packets, one arrives at another Schroedinger equation that is much more amenable to computation in the semiclassical limit project. The third project concerns modeling and efficient simulation of epitaxial growth using kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC). We plan to model and simulate both liquid drop epitaxy and heteroepitaxial growth. In each of these cases we aim to develop highly efficient KMC algorithms to allow simulation on time and lengths not previously possible, thereby facilitating model development and allowing comparison with experiments.

Each of the proposed projects has the potential to have a significant impact on problems that are both fundamental and technologically important. Epitaxial growth is scientifically interesting since it has effects on both nanoscales and mesoscales. It is technologically relevant since quantum dot materials are made in this way. Our proposed techniques will greatly increase the simulation speed thereby facilitating model development. The study of grain boundary motion using curvature flow is a classic problem in applied and computational mathematics which has importance in material science since various properties of polycrystalline substances can crucially depend on the details of the grain patterns. The fast simulation of the semi-classical limit of the Schroedinger equation could provide deeper insight into chemical reaction dynamics, molecular-surface scattering, and photodissociation, for example.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed computational tools for a number of mathematical problems that stem from applications in materials science and engineering. One of its outcomes has been a new algorithm for simulating the evolution of microstructure of polycrystalline materials, which include most metals and ceramics, during manufacturing processes such as annealing. Such materials consist of many crystallites, called grains, stuck together. The internal structure of the material -- the shapes and sizes of the crystallites -- determine its physical characteristics. The project developed a highly efficient algorithm that was then used to carry out very large scale simulations of microstructure evolution. In particular, the asymptotic behavior during annealing of the misorientation distribution function (MDF) -- a statistical characterization of the microstructure that is of interest to materials scientists -- was investigated. It was found that the behavior of MDF depends on the details of the grain boundary energy model used in the simulations.

 

The project also developed numerical methods for simulating heteroepitaxial growth, which is a process used to manufacture a variety of nanostructures, such as quantum dots. It proceeds by slow deposition of a film of a crystalline material on a substrate consisting of a different material. Differences in the preferred lattice spacing of the two materials result in elastic stresses in the deposited film, which is responsible for the formation of 3D structures such as islands known as quantum dots that relieve the stresses. Simulating these phenomena efficiently via the kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) method is challenging, since long range elastic deformations of the film have to be taken into account. The PI and his collaborators have developed highly efficient versions of the KMC method that dramatically improve simulation speed in this setting. It was applied to study 1. the capping of quantum dots, and 2. strained epitaxial growth on periodic arrays of pillars. In particular, in the context of capped quantum dots, it was used to study the method of strain engineering as a procedure to control the height of quantum dots in conjunction with experimental work utilizing cross sectional scanning tunneling microscopy. Good agreement was found between the KMC simulations and the experimentally obtained morphology of quantum dots, suggesting that the simulations using the new algorithm may be useful in predicting the outcome of quantum dot growth process.

 

The third component of the project extended to multiple dimensions a novel and efficient numerical solver for the Schroedinger equation in the semiclassical limit that was developed in the one dimensional setting as part of the PI’s previous NSF support. The semiclassical limit is difficult to compute as solutions becomes highly oscillatory. The challenge is to compute accurate solutions without needing to resolve the high frequency oscillations. This has been done by a clever transformation of the equation, which “extracts” much of the oscillatory nature of the solution and leaves an equation that is more amenable to efficient computation.  Fast solution of the semiclassical limit of Schroedinger’s equation has many important applications, such as simulation of chemical reaction dynamics.
